pros: Helping at risk communities and being able to learn skills outside of job function.
cons: Non-profit so resources seemed be stretched thin on occasion

pros: Wonderful team to work for so many community members to work with who truly care about the health and safety of others and will go above and beyond. The individuals at Terros are valuable assets and create the environment worth coming in for.
cons: Less than ideal work environment for trans or non binary individuals. If there weren’t people actively working there pushing the envelope to help these people little would be accomplished for the LGBTQIA+ community. The office environment can be hostile naturally but in an environment were we talk openly about mental health and marginalized communities; leadership and supervisors should practice what they preach.

pros: Terro’s has great morals and intentions. The work they do and the services they provide are so helpful for SMI patients. It’s great to experience and be apart of.
cons: I don’t think the employees get paid fairly. BHT’s, case managers, etc. are asked to go into the patients homes alone, despite the fact that they are often substance users or highly aggressive. I wish we were paid more for how much we serve our patients, and for the unsafe environments Terro’s asks us to put ourselves in.

job_title: Mobile Crisis Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Terros Crisis is a great place to begin a career because you will learn about resources in the community,  develop keen assessment skills, feel like a real live superhero, and assist people in a moment of acute need. There are many shifts to choose from for optimal work/life balance. Terros offers good benefits. Management is knowledgeable. Coworkers are heart centered and helpful.
cons: The technology and EMR are challenging but workable.

pros: Benefits are alright, but similar companies have even better benefits with better pay.
cons: Terrible new CEO who lacks emotion regulation and puts workers in extremely dangerous situations, then "plays dumb". Most CCs are power tripping. HUGE case loads. No raises for employees who have to take on bigger caseloads because everyone is leaving. They tried to do $1000 bonuses (like $500 after taxes) for people staying for 6+ months instead of giving raises. Terrible pay and burnt out employees, resulting in terrible patient care. They say they care, but they don't. Also, you'll never get higher in the company. Ever. They pretend there's opportunity to grow when there's not. They're tuition reimbursement and assistance is laughable and you have to compete with other employees to have a chance at even getting it. The CEO and super upper management get tax breaks on their salaries, which some of us looked up, while the rest of us have roommates and can't survive without a second job or side gig.

job_title: Mobile Crisis Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Incredibly meaningful work with decent amount of autonomy in the field.
cons: CMH-work always involves the potential to burn out quickly—manage boundaries and self-care accordingly.

job_title: Community Health Worker in Mesa, AZ
pros: Excellent Training Opportunities are always offered.
cons: Was offered Covid differential at Start - then dropped once the COVID warning ended and then I was basically a call center operator.

review_title: Unprofessional, Hostile, and Toxic Work Environment
pros: Having the opportunity to work with the members in need of guidance and support while also ensuring they are provided with proper psychiatric and medical appointments and medications.
cons: Unprofessional and hostile mistreatment towards employees by directors and coordinators. HR allowed mistreatment to continue leading to decline in productivity and negatively impacting multiple employees' well being resulting in leaving the company.

pros: Good PTO. Clinical supervision. Fair pay.
cons: Overworked, poor leadership, high acuity patients

pros: Lots of clients to work with
cons: Overworked and underpaid, job will chew you up and spit you out

review_title: You are just another warm body to them
pros: A good place to look if you need a starter job. Get in, get some experience then get out.
cons: I have never witnessed so much unprofessional, disrespectful, and incompetent behavior from staff in my entire career. Yelling profanities and racial slurs, staff sleeping with clients, gossiping like you are in junior high, bullying/demeaning comments, passive aggressive immature behavior, no support from coworkers or supervisor, lackluster training, not a collaborative atmosphere at all (blow up your phone and email if someone needs something from you but if you do, crickets), demanding help from you on their terms, poor boundaries, expensive health insurance (they now offer interest free loans to be paid out of your check as supposed to offering better insurance). An absolute toxic workplace and culture.

pros: Supportive management staff, they try to listen to staff, can be fun at times
cons: Pay too low to keep employees. Vacancy rate has had current staff doing the work of 3-4 people for years now. No additional compensation for additional work. They offer Stay Bonuses but it's not the same as just giving better salaries.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Staff was generally friendly and welcoming.
cons: The pay was not good.

job_title: Licensed Associate Counselor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Caseload is high for clinical hours. Great learning environment and supportive co workers. Benefits are good.
cons: Caseload is high. Management is non-supportive. Pay is below norm

pros: Good benefits, stable policies, and attainable productivity expectations.
cons: There are many requirements for documentation which can be exhaustive.

job_title: Human Resources Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: You receive experience at your position. Coworkers are very friendly as well as other departments.
cons: HR Managers are mean and not caring for the employees at all. Everything you do wrong is noted in your meetings. You are made to feel worthless. Managers do not practice the core values.

pros:
1) Clients served was an honor.
2) Supervision by a clinical supervisor who is compassionate, supportive and encouraged growth.
3) Free supervision and easy to get hours
cons:
1) Management was cold, lacked empathy, unsupportive of career growth, micromanaging to the point clinical judgement of clinician is ignored even when danger could happen. 
2) Leadership is blind and blindly supports management without taking complaints from employees seriously. Practice manager is known to be rude, scold employees around clients and other employees, and employees have been penalized for coming forward with valid concerns. Upper leadership will always support management and penalize employees for coming forward regarding disregard of company values. 
3) Clinical judgement and proper client care is disregarded as management are always right and have a history of not acknowledging their errors. 
4) No room for progression in career.
5) Lacks cultural competency and fostering an inclusive workplace.
6)Expect a culture that lacks any supportive kuddos. They operate on no news is good news. 
7) They operate as do as I say and not as I do.
8) Management disclosed that the other clinicians could not do their basic job let alone asking for anything more. 
9) Staff meetings are more like do more with your intakes and session notes without more time.
10) Director thinks he’s too good to experience what clinicians experience for intakes.
11) Employees feel under appreciated due to lack of proper leadership. You will work for bosses not leaders.
12) Building can never stay staffed with clinicians. Employees transfer departments to avoid management.
13) Not open to staff ideas or support. 
14) Expect leadership to blindly support management. Management gets away with asking how an employer with an ADA dx can improve their workplace instead of doing reasonable accommodations. 
15) If you experience discrimination or encounter discriminatory behavior they’ll ask you if you’re looking for it and won’t support you. 
16) Management lacks diversity and the core importance of inclusivity.
17) No respect for experience in the field and will only bring it up if they try to put you down.
18) Fairness is a value lacking.

pros: good company, good management, good psychiatrists, easy to learn online platforms for scheduling, good training, flexibility
cons: had a very rude coworker that supervisor didn't made excuses for when I mentioned the situation to them.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I had a good relationship with my boss, who actually stuck up for me and demonstrated that she cared.
cons:
I learned early on never to call anyone. All phones go to voicemail and the other person always denies having received the message. Worse, often they'd have left the company and their extension was still live. I learned to send emails to my target, their boss, and the boss' boss, thus shaming someone into responding. Clients trying to get services had just as much trouble as I did. 

I learned about some pretty egregious ethical violations during my tenure. Worse, when I reported them the response was pretty sluggish.

IT doesn't fix stuff and then lies about it. I went through that for years, consistently.

job_title: Onsite Program Liaison in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Not much pros here at this company
cons: Drama, drama, drama and more drama

pros: Autonomy, left alone, own practice
cons: 15 all visits new, wwe, hospital dc

pros: Flexible leaders, forward thinking, and very ethical
cons: Low paying, high turnover. When programs ask for more staff because they cannot meet the expectations they are told that more staff is never the answer and to figure out another way. It has been years of the same answer, same challenge, same results.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Phoenix, AZ

cons: Pay is considerably more for the job position requirements. After deductions, my take home was enough to pay rent only. I had to take a second and third job to feed my children and cover all other bills. They will work you through a burn out if you allow them, because they are always short staffed.

pros: Good pay and decent benefits package.

Good salary but you will work to death for those dollars.

pros: Some staff are wonderful. Some are really bad.

cons: Burn out is common in this type of work. You don't make a lot of money and you put a lot of miles on your own car. This is the same situation for this position at any company. Terros is a great place to work for.

pros: The team members and the pto were good
cons: Overworked overwhelmed and underpaid for the amount of work they expect you to do

pros: Good work/life balance, industry leader, stable work

I love that the work and the core values align with my own values. Although my role is administrative, I am so impressed with the commitment and caring to patients that I witness from our direct care providers from case managers to clinicians to medical team.
cons: Like all nonprofits, many admin roles wear many hats.

job_title: Substance Abuse Counselor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Terros gave me a chance to get my foot in the door in mental health
cons: They are kinda cheap and don't pay enough

pros: It was all good until it wasn’t
cons: Pay opportunity for growth and lack of ___

pros:
Terros is a not for profit agency. 
Many areas for growth opportunities such as crisis stabilization team, outpatient, substance abuse areas, administration, etc.
Offer staff a bus pass for optional commuting.
cons:
Many staff that had been at Terros for 10+ years are leaving the agency. This is not a good sign. These staff are VP staff and down the line staff.
Terros has a open and community type of seating arrangement that have no assigned seats at many sites. No assigned seats is enforced.
If you cannot meet expectation goals and percentages, you will be counseled and eventually let go if not achieved. You must bill 5+ hours with members. 
Every staff MUST have a fingerprint clearance card, line staff, medical records staff, phone staff, etc.
Terros is one of the lowest paying agencies except of course if you are VP and CEO.  Medical Assistant making 12 an hour and case manager making 13 to 14 an hour.

review_title: Was my time here worth it?
pros: Very quiet.  Management is very friendly.  Commitment to company mission and values.  I worked with some pretty knowledgeable and talented people.  I was lucky to work for a good manager who helped me exceed expectations on annual reviews.
cons: Too many to count.  Too much work, upper management that doesn't have a clue on what they are responsible for, no advancement opportunities, hidden agendas, low salaries (I exceeded expectations and got the highest percentage in the department - 3%), favoritism, can't bring anything to HR (no confidentiality).

pros: Terros is basically the best place I've ever worked at! The job is very fast paced and every day is different but it's actually a great thing. Our prevention staff is actually a team! It's an energetic  environment where I feel I can grow, learn, and gain invaluable experience. Our supervisor is very supportive and caring too! I know it sounds too good to be true, but it's honestly the best.
cons: The hours are pretty intense and the pay is okay but for the amount of work involved, it could be better.

review_title: Worked at Terros for four years
pros: Great co-workers, but don't often last due to limited opportunities.
cons: This company participates in discrimination against people of color. They promote individuals that don't have backgrounds in working with people with issues. Management and HR "encourage" individuals with appropriate educational and personal experienced workers away. Pay is very low and workers are not supported by management.

pros: Being exposed to a diverse population. The targeted population was gay men and IV drug users. I enjoyed helping them find aid when available, educated them not only on HIV but many other topics as well.
cons: A Director that didn't have good personal boundaries with the clients. The higher ups and some board members, couldn't get past their own prejudices and learn that this population and how they run thier lives was similar to their own. The difference being some lived in glass houses and others didn't have a house at all.

pros: Great company. Lots of flexibility. Understanding management. Yearly raises and annual reviews. Organized company. The best behavioral health agency I’ve ever worked at.
cons: A lot of typing. But if you can type it’s not that bad.

job_title: Case Manager in New Tucson, AZ
pros: Excellent mentorship/managers, very flexible hours, training opportunities, a lot of direct work with clients and trust from managers in finding your style/way of building rapport, etc.
cons: A lot of data entry, not so bad once you develop a system but you have to stay on top of it or be slowly buried. Pay so-so but fine for intro BHT position. Language differential in pay if bilingual.

pros: Inspiring core values, cares about community, established company with good reputation
cons: There is a lot expected of staff that doesn't always have clear communication from management, CEO cares more about growth and revenue than keeping current employees happy and retaining the best workers

pros: Training Opportunities, Good Team of Coworkers, Significant Pay Increase with Licensure.
cons: Understaffed. Needed changes don't seem to take place unless you're in a division that's profitable. Pay is not as competitive as other agencies (based on what I've been told). Work-life balance needs improvement (according to my experience and several others I have spoken to).

pros: Large company with good name. Organized, trains well, good place for a beginner starting out in the field. Multiple departments so you can continue to move on or up.
cons: The Central Office is where upper management is so they really have no clue what is going on with the clinics and how they run. Not very competitive salary.

review_title: Overworked and Underpaid "co-location" employee BHT/Therapist- Substance abuse/SMI
pros: Independence to do my work, paid mileage, a lot of seminars and trainings, got my feet wet as a beginning counselor
cons:
These people are all right., especially the first review.  I'll expand on it more:

-I was given very little training on ClaimTrak before I was thrown to the wolves at my clinic, and I was written up because there were errors in my files.  Other employees weren't trained as well and they are all in the same boat. I was closing the other therapists files and making numerous mistakes because I had -0- training at that point with claimtrak.  I still continue to get blamed for his mistakes. We haven't billed Magellan for our work because our client files are so badly messed up.  Management is blaming the 11 employees in our colo program when they had no formal training PERIOD.  Why not take 2 days and train everyone at once?  Even the supervisors are constantly changing their minds about what information to enter into client files!
-If you work at a CO LOCATION as a BHT, you do the same work as CLINICIANS who are paid more.  15.25 is my wage for a masters level counselor.  After a year you're lucky to get a 30% raise.  
-We have to do ALL of the paperwork, client intake information which takes FOREVER, on top of soliciting our own clients from the case managers and addressing their numerous concerns, and trying to convince them why they should give you referrals, you have to attend their morning meetings as well.  Tracking down our clients when they don't show, attending seminars, supervisions, case management activities ourselves, and it leave very little time to do client care.   Why am I being paid so little to do 4 jobs?
    -Other agencies and other programs at Terros have their own intake people, they don't have to solicit their clients from frustrated case managers, they don't have to worry about clients CONSTANTLY missing their sessions because of unreliable cab service, their mental illness, and their case loads are nowhere near as heavy.  Terros overworks its colo employees. My job is 20:80  20 percent client care, 80 percent paperwork and case management and cleaning up messes. 
-Health insurance is awful.  For blood work two times and 2 doctors appointments I have to come up with 700 out of pocket!  There are no copays.  you have to either hit a 2k or 1.5k deductible.  
-Pay has been frozen for years
-No opportunity for advancement whatsoever
-I am all alone at my clinic, and if I have a question, it takes forever for people to respond because they're so busy.

If you're a masters level counselor, APPLY SOMEWHERE ELSE.  Lifewell pays 3 dollars an hour more for this same position.  Apply elsewhere period.

review_title: Terrible company to work for, do not even apply!
pros: CEO and VPs are great and very personable.  Company has a great purpose and do great work with the community but internally needs a lot of work.
cons: Poor leadership, do not address poor work performance appropriately, salary, benefits, quality of people, turnover, too much office politics, cannot wear fragrance whatsoever, coworkers have no loyalty to each other.

review_title: Great learning experience, issues with middle management.
pros: Variety of work experiences available, committed senior management, fair pay.
cons: lot of politics at middle management, arguing, etc.

review_title: Terros is great place to work.

cons: Watch what you say in public. Someone is always listening.  If you have something to say that is negative, keep it to yourself.

pros:
great co workers 
a unique experience working in crisis, always changing

pros: I enjoyed working for a nonprofit, and helping making lives for the better.

pros: Friendly coworkers, growth opportunities and   many in leadership who make the extra effort to retain employees and show they care!
